Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: Quantifying and Exploiting the Structure of Phylogenetic Tree Space Through Network Analyses
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop a rich and flexible mathematical framework for quantifying the phylogenetic signal (i.e., the information about genealogical relationships among organisms) contained within big data sets of genome sequences. To quantify this signal, the relationships among different phylogenetic trees, or the branches in those trees, will be conceptualized as networks. The structure of these networks provides biologically meaningful information about the degree and causes of phylogenetic uncertainty and conflict. The newly developed framework will be implemented in publicly available software useable as a standalone application and as a webservice. In addition, the core functionality of the developed software will be closely integrated with other ongoing NSF-funded efforts to reconstruct and explore the Tree of Life (iPlant and the Open Tree of Life).

This work will draw from expertise in evolutionary biology, computer science, and applied mathematics. Research activities will involve the direct contributions of both graduate and undergraduate researchers and software developers. Undergraduates will learn to code from graduate students in mentor-apprentice relationships. An undergraduate science communications student will develop a website illustrating phylogenetic principles and applied phylogenetic research, highlighting novel insights provided by the methods developed. Additionally, several in-person and remote training workshops will be held to introduce and familiarize researchers with newly developed tools. An ongoing computational biology seminar series targeted towards undergraduates will be held at Louisiana State University. The methods developed as part of this project will improve our ability to understand phylogenetic information, which is integral to a variety of applications in conservation, forensics, agriculture, and epidemiology. Updates on project progress and links to developed tools will be available at http://www.phyleauxgenetics.org/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were to develop mathematical methods and software tools for visually and quantitatively comparing large sets of phylogenetic trees, each of which depicts the evolutionary relationships among a set of species, genes, populations, or individuals. In the modern era of cheap genome sequencing, biologists can use thousands of genes from across the genome to reconstruct historical relationships. However, some genes exhibit considerable uncertainty in their estimates of these relationships and genes often differ in their preferred tree. Therefore, the output of many phylogenetic studies is not a single tree, but rather a set of trees.

In this project, we leveraged the well developed mathematics of networks to provide tools that can create two- and three-dimensional visualizations of tree sets, as well as identify distinct communities of trees. To identify communities, we also created a new type of network whose basic components (nodes) are actually parts of trees (known as bipartitions), rather than the trees themselves. Simulation tests show that the new bipartition networks may outperform tree-based networks in identifying strong phylogenetic conflict. Overall, these tools allow us to address a number of important questions in phylogenetics, including (i) identifying genes that support very unusual trees, (ii) identifying 'rogue' species whose phylogenetic position is very difficult to determine, (iii) rigorously comparing phylogenetic estimates from different data sets, (iv) identifying taxa formed by hybridization, and (v) identifying genes that may have been transferred across species boundaries (horizontal gene transfer).

To facilitate the use of the methods, we created software called TreeScaper (https://github.com/whuang08/TreeScaper). TreeScaper is written in C++ and distributed as open-source code, as well as executables for Mac, Linux, and Windows operating systems. Both graphical (GUI) and command-line versions of the program are available, making it possible for users of many different skill levels to employ our methods on projects that range widely in scale and scope. TreeScaper is accompanied by a detailed manual that contains both a quickstart tutorial and a full description of available commands. In addition, we developed materials for a workshop that are now freely available online for any interested users (https://github.com/ssb2017/treescaper).

Beyond the intellectual merit of the research itself, this project created a multitude of training and educational opportunities. The interdisciplinary nature of the research and the collaboration required graduate students in both the biological sciences and mathematics to collaborate directly with each other and with other researchers in disciplines outside their area of expertise. In total, seven graduate students were involved in this work which spanned algorithm implementation, software development, and simulation testing. All students also gained hands-on experience with drafting manuscripts, posters, and talks. Some also created and led workshops and provided other training to potential users of the TreeScaper software. This project also helped to intellectually support a seminar series at Louisiana State that focuses on the contributions of mathematics and computing to modern biological research. Monthly seminars were held in the evenings and targeted towards undergraduates, with biologists describing how various cutting-edge research projects in biology would not have been possible without the use of mathematical and computational tools. Beyond education, the tools that we have developed will result in more accurate and robust results from phylogenetic studies, impacting applied areas as diverse as medicine, conservation, agriculture, forensics, and epidemiology.
